sen.j: 乾漆造（かんしつぞう）とは、東洋における彫像制作の技法の1つで、麻布を漆で張り重ねたり、漆と木粉を練り合わせたものを盛り上げて像を形づくる方法である。
sen.e: Kanshitsuzo (or kanshitsu zukuri, literally, dry lacquer technique) is one of the oriental wood statue production techniques, in which a statue is formed by layering pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer over a core, and the wood powder/lacquer mixture was thickly applied to create surface details.

Kanshitsuzo (or kanshitsu zukuri, literally, dry lacquer technique) is one of the oriental wood statue production techniques, in which a statue is formed by layering pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer over a core, and a wood powder/lacquer mixture was thickly applied to create surface details.

Kanshitsuzo (literally, dry lacquer technique) is one of the oriental wood statue production techniques, in which a statue is formed by layering pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer over a core, and a wood powder and lacquer mixture was thickly applied to create surface details.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Overview
Overview
Summary

sen.j: 乾漆造の源流は中国にあり、中国では「夾紵」（きょうちょ）あるいは「ソク（土扁に「塞」）」と呼ばれた技法である。
sen.e: The kanshitsuzo technique originates in China, where the technique is called 夾紵 (kyocho in Japanese pronunciation) or 塞 with semantic determinative 土 on the left side (soku in Japanese pronunciation).

The kanshitsuzo technique originates in China, where the technique is called 夾紵 (kyocho in Japanese pronunciation) or 塞 with semantic determinative 土 on the left side (soku in Japanese pronunciation).

The kanshitsuzo technique originates in China, where the technique is called '夾紵' (kyocho in Japanese pronunciation) or '塞' with semantic determinative 土 on the left side (soku in Japanese pronunciation).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 彫像のみならず器物や棺などの製作にも用いられた。
sen.e: In addition to statues, the technique was also used to produce containers, coffins, and other objects.
In addition to statues, the technique was also used to produce containers, coffins, and other objects.
In addition to statues, the technique was also used to produce containers, coffins, and other objects.

sen.j: 日本では7世紀末から8世紀にかけて仏像の制作に多用されたが、平安時代以降は衰退した。
sen.e: In Japan, the technique was frequently used in Buddha statues from the end of 7th century to 8th century, and declined in Heian period or later.
In Japan, the technique was frequently used for Buddhist statues from the end of the 7th century to the 8th century, and declined during Heian period or later.
In Japan, the technique was frequently used for Buddhist statues from the end of the 7th century to the 8th century, and declined during Heian period or later.

sen.j: 乾漆造には麻布を1センチほどの厚みに貼り重ねて形成する「脱活乾漆造」と、これを簡略化した技法と思われる「木心乾漆造」がある。
sen.e: Kanshitsuzo has two types: Dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo, or hollow dry lacquer technique, in which pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer are layered to a thickness of 1cm; and mokushin-kanshitsuzo, or wood-core dry lacquer technique, which is a simplified version of the former dry lacquer technique.

Kanshitsuzo has two types: Dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo, or the hollow dry lacquer technique, where pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer are layered to a thickness of 1cm; and mokushin-kanshitsuzo, or wood-core dry lacquer technique, which is a simplified version of the former dry lacquer technique.

Kanshitsuzo has two types: 'Dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo,' the hollow dry lacquer technique, where pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer are layered to a thickness of 1 cm; and 'mokushin-kanshitsuzo,' wood-core dry lacquer technique, which is a simplified version of the former dry lacquer technique.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 脱活乾漆造
sen.e: Dakkatsu kanshitsuzo (Hollow dry lacquer technique)
Dakkatsu kanshitsuzo (Hollow dry lacquer technique)
Dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせ、補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 制作方法を簡単に説明すると次のとおりである。
sen.e: The method of production can be simply expressed as follows:
The method of production can be simply expressed as follows:
The method of production can be simply expressed as follows:

sen.j: まず、木製の芯木で像の骨組みをつくり、その上に粘土（塑土）を盛り上げて像の概形をつくる。
sen.e: First, the framework of the statue is made using shingi or wooden core, over which clay is applied to create a rough core.
First, the framework of the statue is made using shingi or a wooden core, over which clay is applied to create a rough statue.
First, the framework of the statue is made using shingi (a wooden core), over which clay is applied to create a rough statue.

sen.j: この上に麻布を麦漆で貼り重ねて像の形をつくる。
sen.e: On top of the clay surface, pieces of hemp cloth are layered with mugi-urushi to create a basic shape of the statue.
On top of the clay surface, pieces of hemp cloth are laid with mugi-urushi to create the basic shape of the statue.
On top of the clay surface, pieces of hemp cloth are laid with mugi-urushi (Japanese lacquer mixed with wheat flour) to create the basic shape of the statue.

sen.j: 麦漆とは漆に麦粉（メリケン粉のようなもの）を混ぜてペースト状にしたもので、接着力が強い。
sen.e: Mugi-urushi is a paste mixture of urushi or lacquer and wheat flour, which gives strong bond.
Mugi-urushi is a paste mixture of urushi or lacquer and wheat flour, which creates a strong bond.
Mugi-urushi is a paste mixture of urushi (lacquer) and wheat flour, which creates a strong bond.

sen.j: 麻布の大きさ、貼り重ねる厚さなどは像によって異なるが、おおむね1センチほどの厚さにする。
sen.e: While the size of each hemp piece and thickness of the hemp layer vary from statue to statue, the hemp layer is typically made into roughly about 1 cm thickness.
While the size of each hemp piece and thickness of the hemp layer vary from statue to statue, the hemp layer is typically made into roughly about 1-cm thickness.
While the size of each hemp piece and thickness of the hemp layer vary from statue to statue, the hemp layer is typically made into roughly about 1-cm thickness.

sen.j: こうしてできた張り子の像の上に抹香漆（まっこううるし）または木屑漆（こくそうるし）を盛り上げて細部を形づくる。
sen.e: To the statue core formed in this way, makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the detail of the statue.
To basic statue formed in this way, makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the details of the statue.
To basic statue formed in this way, makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the details of the statue.

sen.j: 抹香漆とは、麦漆にスギ、マツなどの葉の粉末を混ぜたものであり、木屑漆とは麦漆におがくず（ヒノキ材をのこぎりで曳いた際のくず）や紡績くずなどを混ぜたものである。
sen.e: Makko-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding leaf powder of cedar, pine tree, etc. to a paste made of lacquer and flour; kokuso-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding sawdust of cypress, textile scraps, etc. to a paste made of lacquer and flour.

Makko-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding leaf powder of cedar, pine tree, etc. to a paste made of lacquer and flour; kokuso-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding cypress sawdust, textile scraps, etc. to a paste made of lacquer and flour.

Makko-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding leaf powder of cedar, pine tree, and so on, to mugi-urushi; kokuso-urushi is a mixture prepared by adding cypress sawdust, textile scraps, and so on, to mugi-urushi.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせ、補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 奈良時代には抹香漆、平安時代以降は木屑漆が主に使われた。
sen.e: In Nara era, makko-urushi, and in Heian era and beyond, kokuso-urushi were chiefly used.
During the Nara era, makko-urushi, and during the Heian era and beyond, kokuso-urushi were chiefly used.
During the Nara period, makko-urushi, and during the Heian period and later, kokuso-urushi were mainly used.

sen.j: なお、像の形が完成した後は、背面などの目立たない部分を切開して中味の塑土を掻き出し、補強と型崩れ防止のために内部に木枠を組む。
sen.e: When the whole shape of the statue has been modeled, the clay inside the core is scraped out from a hole which was cut in an inconspicuous place such as on the back of the statue; then a wooden framework is placed inside the statue for reinforcement and preventing warping.

When the whole shape of the statue had been modeled, the clay inside the core is scraped out from a hole which was cut in an inconspicuous place such as on the back of the statue; then wooden framework is placed inside the statue for reinforcement and to prevent warpage.

When the whole shape of the statue had been modeled, the clay inside the core is scraped out from a hole which was cut in an inconspicuous place such as on the back of the statue; then wooden framework is placed inside the statue for reinforcement and to prevent warpage.

sen.j: この技法による像は、東大寺法華堂（三月堂）、興福寺、唐招提寺などに現存し、日本彫刻史上著名な作品が多く含まれる。
sen.e: Statues made by this method still exist in Todai-ji Temple Hokkedo (Sangatsudo), Kofuku-ji Temple, Toshodai-ji Temple, many of which are some of the most celebrated work in the history of sculpture in Japan.

Statues made with this method still exist in Todai-ji Temple Hokkedo (Sangatsudo), Kofuku-ji Temple, Toshodai-ji Temple, many of which are some of the most celebrated works in the history of sculpture in Japan.

Statues made with this method still exist including at Hokkedo (Sangatsudo) in Todai-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, and Toshodai-ji Temple, many of which are some of the most celebrated works in the history of sculpture in Japan.

sen.j: しかし、高価な漆を大量に用いるうえ、制作にも手間がかかるため、平安時代以降はほとんどつくられなくなった。
sen.e: In Heian period and beyond, however, very few statues were made by this method, due to the large amount of costly lacquer required, and the time-consuming processes.
During the Heian period and after, however, very few statues were made by this method, due to the large amount of costly lacquer required, and the time-consuming process.
During the Heian period and after, however, very few statues were made by this method, due to the large amount of costly urushi required, and the time-consuming process.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 奈良・当麻寺（たいまでら）金堂の四天王立像は、破損甚大ながら、日本における脱活乾漆像の最古例と見なされる。
sen.e: The Shitenno ryuzo, or standing statues of Four Heavenly Kings in Taima-dera Temple, Kondo, in Nara City is believed to be the oldest example of statues made by the hollow dry lacquer method.
The Shitenno ryuzo, or standing statues of Four Heavenly Kings in the Taima-dera Temple, Kondo, in Nara City is believed to be the oldest example of statues made by the hollow dry lacquer method.
The Shitenno ryuzo (standing statue of the Four Devas) in Kondo of Taima-dera Temple in Nara City is severely damaged and believed to be the oldest example of statues made by Dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせ、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 木心乾漆造
sen.e: Mokushin kanshitsuzo (Wood core dry lacquer technique)
Mokushin kanshitsuzo (Wood core dry lacquer technique)
Mokushin-kanshitsuzo
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 像の概形を木彫でつくり、この上に麻布を貼り、抹香漆または木屑漆を盛り上げて完成させる像である。
sen.e: In this technique, a rough-shaped core is made by carving wood, which is covered by layers of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer, and makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the detail over the statue core.

In this technique, a roughly-shaped core is made by carving wood, which is covered by layers of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer, and makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the detail over the rough statue.

In this technique, a roughly-shaped core is made by carving wood, which is covered by layers of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer, and makko-urushi or kokuso-urushi is applied to build up the detail over the rough statue.

sen.j: 脱活乾漆像が中空の像であるのに対し、木心乾漆像の像内には木心が残ったままであり、麻布もさほど厚くは貼らない。
sen.e: While statues made by the hollow dry lacquer technique are hollow, those made by the wood core dry lacquer technique have a wood core inside with the hemp cloth layer being thinner than the former technique.

While statues made by the hollow dry lacquer technique are hollow, those made by the wood core dry lacquer technique have a wood core inside with the hemp cloth layer being thinner than the former technique.
While statues of dakkatsu-kanshitsuzo are hollow, mokushin-kanshitsuzo have a wood core inside with the hemp cloth layer being thinner than the former technique.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わ補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 平安時代前期の仏像の中には、木彫り像の一部に木心乾漆技法を併用して表情、装身具などの細部を形づくっている例も多く、「木造」か「木心乾漆造」か、機械的に分けるのが困難な場合もある。
sen.e: Some Buddha statues in early Heian period were made based on carved wood figures, partially by the wood core dry lacquer method to create details such as facial expression and accessories; therefore, in some cases, it is difficult to categorize into "carved wood figure" or "wood core dry lacquer technique" in a uniform manner.

Some Buddhist statues in early Heian period were made based on carved wood figures, partially by the wood core dry lacquer method to create details such as facial expressions and accessories; therefore, in some cases, it is difficult to categorize them into "carved wood figure" or "wood core dry lacquer technique."

Some Buddhist statues in the early Heian period were made based on carved wood figures, partially by mokushin-kanshitsuzo to create details such as facial expressions and accessories; therefore, in some cases, it is difficult to categorize them into 'carved wood figure' or 'mokushin-kanshitsuzo' (wood core dry lacquer technique) by rule.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせ補足しました。 early Heian period→the early Heian periodに変更しました。
